summary:
The 2010 Haiti earthquake was a devastating 7.0 magnitude quake that hit near Léogâne, about 16 miles west of Port-au-Prince, on January 12, 2010. It caused widespread destruction, affecting three million people and killing an estimated 100,000 to 316,000. Many buildings collapsed, including landmarks like the Presidential Palace.

International aid poured in, but challenges like damaged infrastructure and coordination issues hindered relief efforts. As rescues ended, focus shifted to providing supplies, medical care, and sanitation. Looting and violence were reported due to aid distribution delays. The Haitian government officially ended the search for survivors on January 23.
title: 2010 Haiti earthquake
